3.21.18  12:56 pm   what's your take on changing tempos of songs when you play live? do you think doing some songs a bit faster or slower would be fun?

     yes, and also changing them in many more ways

     or do you feel that the original tempos are ideal

     sure

      and shouldn't be changed?

     changing the tempo, groove, and arrangement of songs is something so valuable and richly enjoyable that i would like to be doing it every day for breakfast

3.21.18  11:08 am   why do you take the music-related questions seriously?

     well i'm glad i helped you escape from the purpose you came here

      what do you think most people come here for?

     questions

     
SORRY that's two question

3.21.18  9:47 am   hey bill how do i ear train to get an ear like the ones you have I'm a bass player 

      it happens automatically, the more you play, the more you hear, it's inevitable that you will learn what's going on. it's like living with a family of inuit eskimos. you are going to learn the inuit language, that's just what's going to happen

3.21.18  9:07 am   Take a wild guess... about what percent of the words in the dictionary do you think you know the definition of?

      you didn't say which dictionary and whether you meant the actual verbatim definition, nor what percentage of the different meanings listed, but in general i might estimate that it's less than 45%. there's a lot of fuckin words in there. but another thing that i think is worth mentioning is that i know a lot of words that wouldn't be in the dictionary, and so do you

3.21.18  9:01 am   "diminished" gets brought up only when discussing chords and intervals it seems, "flat" is a modifier to a note and nothing more. however, diminishing an interval means making one note flat, that's why it gets so confusing.

when we say Cdim we mean C/Eb/Gb. When we say Cdim7 is the seventh also diminished (C/Eb/Gb/Bbb=A)?

     yes

     If yes, what do we call C/Eb/Gb/Bb?

     that is called either "half diminished" or "minor 7 flat 5" depending on which community you are in

      And what about a major seventh in an otherwise diminished C/Eb/Gb/B?

     "B over C"

3.21.18  8:55 am   In christianity, do they believe that jesus is literally the son of god, or is he supposed to be god in human form? Are they 2 separate entities that can communicate with each other and stuff, or does god just talk/act in the form of jesus? I know in the bible, there are prophets who speak with god.. but does jesus speak with god? Or no, because he is god? This always confused me. I know everyone can have their own personal beliefs and interpretations and stuff... but what's the traditional view on this?

      it depends how far back you go. it seems to me that it was just a cult following of a brillantly wise and inspirational man, before Rome bought the rights and added all the hollywood magic, perhaps with some extra ambiguities baked in to keep you on your best behaviour $$

3.21.18  8:14 am   john cage in 4`33 was the idea that even nothing could be music.

     that's the oldest trick in the book. it blows me away that 1 man has received that much credit for an idea as old as humanity

     can there be a something that isn't music?

     i'll leave that up to the scientists

3.20.18  11:04 pm   Is skydiving still the worst thing in the world to you?

     it never was. i've never done it and never plan to but it sounds neat and it is a metaphor i frequently use for performing in front of a live audience, or even just meeting someone you have never met before

     My worst thing is locked-in syndrome, which is fortunately not MY worst thing, since I'm typing this right now.

3.20.18  9:22 pm   When and how did note name/pitches become standardized (at least in western music)?

     i don't know

      I know it's not totally standard. Sometimes people tune up or down or whatever.. but who decided "let's call this note A, and let's all make sure our A's are the same"? Was there some Important European Music Council that got together and made a declaration, then sent letters out to all the famous composers? 

     i don't know

     not exactly

3.20.18  7:31 pm   im in that audience of one situation. i love my work, i love myself. all my anxieties are that others might not feel the same. i try to mask how much i like what i do and say because im worried that people who don't like my stuff will think i have bad taste. i think im one stylish motherfucker and i don't know how to spread the steeze so i can accumulate an audience. don't know the specific steps to do it louder

     a good way to prepare for the inevitable reveal is to make sure you have a safe space to line up all your works in whatever order you originally meant them. then imagine you have an audience, and imagine they are the perfect audience. and carry on like this for quite a while. then when you are in the mood, start discretely letting people in on the secret. and by then it will look like an assured and reckonable phenomenon

3.20.18  4:01 pm   I thought C7 meant Cmaj + minor 7, not Cmaj + diminished 7? Or are they the same thing?

     actually now that i think of it, diminished 7 actually means double flat 7. or if you are in a reasonable mood, just 6. but for clarity's sake i would prefer to call that Bb a flat 7, instead of saying minor 7, because minor 7 is the name of a chord which also includes the minor 3rd

3.20.18  3:59 pm   what's your take of Nihilism

     it is not something i am familiar with

3.20.18  3:52 pm   3.20.18  3:57 am "C Db, D#, E, Gb, G#, Bb". the same notes as Db melodic minor but starting on C.

     if it were me i'd just say whole tone with the D flipped out to Db and D# instead, IF those notes you listed were the exact notes i needed. probably a lot of people would say altered but i just think there is ambiguity surrounding those situations, both in the terminology and in the reality. in places where the 'altered' scale is typically used, in your key, it would be like if you're on a C7("alt")(which could mean anything from b9 to #9 to +5) about to go to Fmin. and i think in reality your strongest notes are going to be Db, Eb, Bb, Ab, E, and then i'd say tied for the next lesser level of priority would be like F and G, and furthermore this entire umrella of chord scenarios (the C7"alt" to Fmin) in general is very friendly to dense chromatic passing tones, so the remaining notes will immediately go onto the table. this has included some of the notes not in your scale, and also i might add that i think Gb is least likely to be a good choice, actually quite frankly i don't think Gb would belong in the 'altered' scale, if we're talking about what really is strongest for most of the situations where 'alt' is written in the chord symbol. as you study a lot of tunes from the same time period, same composer, etc., you may notice them consistantly using a certain type of 'dark' V7 chord (C7 going to Fmin, in our key) and 'alt' may seem like a friendly concept within the context of one particular time period or composer, but as you travel from decade to decade you'll notice that the 'typical' scenarios become slightly different, and yet still pronounced. some calling strongly for the C7b9, or others more strongly calling for #9 and +5. just when you think you have found the archetypical type within a certain time period or sector of music, move just a few steps and you will find it's different and yet also seemingly archetypical. but i would like to repeat something i said earlier which is sure you can absolutely call your series of notes by either of the 2 previous names first mentioned in the original question, they are perfectly justified names. but be ready to clarify what notes you want if the person says 'what'
